member.name: T:Sudoku.Buffers.FastProperties
member.summary: Provides and encapsulates the fast properties that is used in solving and analyzing a sudoku puzzle.

remarks.para: The whole class is a one, which means you can't use clause to create a new instance of this type. In contrast, the class is used for providing with properties used in a cyclic manually searching (i.e. in ).
Some step searchers rely on this type. If you want to call them separately, you should ensure the method in this type must be called before using these properties.

If a step searcher doesn't rely on this class, it'll be for the property named . If you find that the step searcher marks that attribute, you can call it everywhere safely; however, if the searcher isn't marked that attribute, you can't call it everywhere unless you call the method .

Please note, all names of properties in this class can also be found in , which means you can also call the property by . Of course, some of them doesn't contain the same one in , but you can find a same property whose execution logic (handling logic) is totally same. For example, is same as . The difference between them is that you shouldn't use until you have called , while can be used everywhere, because it isn't an instant property (which means the calculation begins when you called them, i.e. lazy ones; in contrast, some properties only store values directly, so their values can be got instantly, i.e. instant ones).

member.name: M:Sudoku.Compatibility.Hodoku.HodokuLibraryCompatiblity.GetHodokuPrefix(Sudoku.Techniques.Technique)
member.summary: Try to get the prefix of the specified technique. The return value will be a four-digit value represented as a value. For more information please visit this link.

returns.para: A value using a four-digit value to describe a technique used in a sudoku grid, which is defined by the project Hodoku.
If this technique is not supported by Hodoku, will be returned.

remarks.para: Please note that some technique fields are separated into multiple sub-types, but they all belong to a same type of a technique supported by Hodoku. For example, and are supported by Hodoku as one technique "Sue de Coq", so if you get the prefix from the two fields, the return value are same (i.e. the value "1101").

member.exception: Throws when the specified value is not defined by the type , or the value is .

member.name: T:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap
member.summary: Encapsulates a binary series of cell status table.
member.remarks:
This type holds a field called , it is the only field provided to be used as the entry to create or update collection. If you want to add elements into it, you can use , or just or :
var cellMap = CellMap.Empty; cellMap += 0; // Adds 'r1c1' into the collection. cellMap.Add(0); // Adds 'r1c2' into the collection. cellMap.AddRange(stackalloc[] { 2, 3, 4 }); // Adds 'r1c345' into the collection. cellMap |= anotherCellMap; // Adds a list of another instance of type 'CellMap' into the current collection.
If you want to learn more information about this type, please visit this wiki page.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap._high
member.summary:
Indicates the internal two values, which represents 81 bits. represent the higher 40 bits and represents the lower 41 bits, where each bit is:
bit (1) The corresponding cell is contained in this collection
bit (0) The corresponding cell is not contained in this collection

member.name: F:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap._low
member.summary:
Indicates the internal two values, which represents 81 bits. represent the higher 40 bits and represents the lower 41 bits, where each bit is:
bit (1) The corresponding cell is contained in this collection
bit (0) The corresponding cell is not contained in this collection

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.BlockMask
member.summary: Indicates the mask of block that all cells in this collection spanned.
member.remarks: For example, if the cells are { 0, 1, 27, 28 }, all spanned blocks are 0 and 3, so the return mask is 0b000001001 (i.e. 9).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.RowMask
member.summary: Indicates the mask of row that all cells in this collection spanned.
member.remarks: For example, if the cells are { 0, 1, 27, 28 }, all spanned rows are 0 and 3, so the return mask is 0b000001001 (i.e. 9).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.ColumnMask
member.summary: Indicates the mask of column that all cells in this collection spanned.
member.remarks: For example, if the cells are { 0, 1, 27, 28 }, all spanned columns are 0 and 1, so the return mask is 0b000000011 (i.e. 3).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.CoveredLine
member.summary: Indicates the covered line.
member.remarks: If the covered house can't be found, it'll return .

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.Count
member.summary: Indicates the number of the values stored in this collection.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.CoveredHouses
member.summary: Indicates all houses covered. This property is used to check all houses that all cells of this instance covered. For example, if the cells are { 0, 1 }, the property will return the house index 0 (block 1) and 9 (row 1); however, if cells spanned two houses or more (e.g. cells { 0, 1, 27 }), this property won't contain any houses.
member.remarks: The return value will be an value indicating each houses. Bits set 1 are covered houses.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.Houses
member.summary: All houses that the map spanned. This property is used to check all houses that all cells of this instance spanned. For example, if the cells are { 0, 1 }, the property will return the house index 0 (block 1), 9 (row 1), 18 (column 1) and 19 (column 2).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.ExpandedPeers
member.summary: Gets the expanded peers of the current map.
member.remarks: An Expanded Peers is a list of cells that contains all peer cells of each cell appeared in the current collection. For example, if a collection contains cells r1c123, this collection will be the result of the expression PeersMap[r1c1] | PeersMap[r1c2] | PeersMap[r1c3], which uses the array .

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.PeerIntersection
member.summary: Indicates the peer intersection of the current instance.
member.remarks: A Peer Intersection is a set of cells that all cells from the base collection can be seen. For more information please visit this link.

member.returns:
All possible subsets. If:
Condition Meaning
> .Count Will return an empty array
== .Count

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.op_Modulus(Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@)
member.summary: Expands the operator to (a & b).PeerIntersection & b.
member.param: The template map that the base map to check and cover.

remarks.para: The operator is commonly used for checking eliminations, especially in type 2 of deadly patterns.

For example, if we should check the eliminations of digit d, we may use the expression
(urCells & grid.CandidatesMap[d]).PeerIntersection & grid.CandidatesMap[d]
to express the eliminations are the peer intersection of cells of digit d appeared in urCells. This expression can be simplified to
urCells % grid.CandidatesMap[d]

member.name: F:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.Solver
member.summary: Indicates the solver that uses the bitwise algorithm to solve a puzzle as fast as possible.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid._values
member.summary: Indicates the inner array that stores the masks of the sudoku grid, which stores the in-time sudoku grid inner information.
member.remarks:
The field uses the mask table of length 81 to indicate the status and all possible candidates holding for each cell. Each mask uses a value, but only uses 11 of 16 bits.
16 8 0 |-------|-------| | |--|--------| 16 12 9 0
Here the first-nine bits indicate whether the digit 1-9 is possible candidate in the current cell respectively, and the higher 3 bits indicate the cell status. The possible cell status are:
Status name Description
Empty cell (i.e. ) The cell is currently empty, and wait for being filled.
Modifiable cell (i.e. )
The cell is filled by a digit, but the digit isn't the given by the initial grid.
Given cell (i.e. )
The cell is filled by a digit, which is given by the initial grid and can't be modified.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.#ctor
member.summary: Throws a .
member.exception: The exception will always be thrown.
member.remarks: The main idea of the parameterless constructor is to create a new instance without any extra information, but the current type is special: the author wants to make you use another member instead of it to get a better experience. Therefore, the parameterless constructor is disallowed to be invoked no matter what kind of invocation, reflection or strongly reference.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.#ctor(System.Int32@,Sudoku.Concepts.GridCreatingOption)
member.summary: Creates a instance via the pointer of the first element of the cell digit, and the creating option.

param.name: firstElement
param.para: The reference of the first element.

target.name: in-parameter
target.i: Please note that the parameter is an parameter, which has the same meaning for returns or locals. You can treat it as the first element in an array of elements. Different with parameter, modifier has the same semantic as instead of .

target.name: method
target.i:
C# 7.3 introduces a new keyword as the parameter modifier to make the parameter pass by reference and be read-only. Therefore, this keyword contains 2 usages:
Ensure the argument to be read-only and cannot be modified. Otherwise, a new copied instance will be created to prevent any modifications on the original variable.
Ensure the argument to pass by reference in order to treat it as the pointer or array of elements of this type, and treat the argument as the first element of the whole element series.
From the above meaning on this keyword, we can conclude that we should regard it as parameters, but C# requires us using the keyword as the modifier on a parameter rather than .

member.exception: Throws when the argument is reference.

summary.para: Indicates the constructor of the current type.
This constructor will initialize some data members of this type that can't use a simple expression to describe the initial value.

summary.para: Indicates which houses are null houses.
A Null House is a house whose hold cells are all empty cells.

The property returns an value as a mask that contains all possible house indices. For example, if the row 5, column 5 and block 5 (1-9) are null houses, the property will return the result value, 000010000_000010000_000010000 as binary.

summary.para: Indicates the map of possible positions of the existence of each digit. The return value will be an array of 9 elements, which stands for the statuses of 9 digits.
Different with , this property contains all givens, modifiables and empty cells only if it contains the digit in the mask.
Indicates the map of possible positions of the existence of that value of each digit. The return value will be an array of 9 elements, which stands for the statuses of 9 digits.
Different with , the value only contains the given or modifiable cells whose mask contain the set bit of that digit.

member.summary: Gets or sets the digit that has been filled in the specified cell.
member.param: The cell you want to get or set a value.

value.para: The value you want to set. The value should be between 0 and 8. If assigning -1, that means to re-compute all candidates.

The values set into the grid will be regarded as the modifiable values. If the cell contains a digit, it will be covered when it is a modifiable value. If the cell is a given cell, the setter will do nothing.

member.returns:
The value that the cell filled with. The possible values are:
-1 The status of the specified cell is .
>= 0 and < 9
The actual value that the cell filled with. 0 is for the digit 1, 1 is for the digit 2, etc..
member.exception: Throws when the specified cell keeps a wrong cell status value. For example, .

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.ExactlyValidate(Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,System.Nullable{System.Boolean}@)

summary.para: Determines whether the current grid is valid, checking on both normal and sukaku cases and returning a ? value indicating whether the current sudoku grid is valid only on sukaku case.
For more information, please see the introduction about the parameter .

member.param: The solution if the puzzle is valid; otherwise, .

Indicates whether the current mode is sukaku mode.
The puzzle is a sukaku puzzle.
The puzzle is a normal sudoku puzzle.
The puzzle is invalid.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.Exists(System.Int32)
member.summary: Indicates whether the current grid contains the specified candidate offset.
member.returns:
The method will return a ? value (contains three possible cases: , and ). All values corresponding to the cases are below:
The cell that the candidate specified is an empty cell and contains the specified digit that the candidate specified.
The cell that the candidate specified is an empty cell but doesn't contain the specified digit that the candidate specified.
The cell that the candidate specified is not an empty cell that the candidate specified.
member.remarks: Note that the method will return a ?, so you should use the code 'grid.Exists(candidate) is true' or 'grid.Exists(candidate) == true' to decide whether a condition is true.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.Exists(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Indicates whether the current grid contains the digit in the specified cell.
member.returns:
The method will return a ? value (contains three possible cases: , and ). All values corresponding to the cases are below:
The cell is an empty cell and contains the specified digit.
The cell is an empty cell but doesn't contain the specified digit.
The cell is not an empty cell.

remarks.para: Note that the method will return a ?, so you should use the code 'grid.Exists(cell, digit) is true' or 'grid.Exists(cell, digit) == true' to decide whether a condition is true.
In addition, because the type is ? rather than , the result case will be more precisely than the indexer , which is the main difference between this method and that indexer.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.ToArray
member.summary: Serializes this instance to an array, where all digit value will be stored.
member.returns: This array. All elements are between 0 to 9, where 0 means the cell is now.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.GetMask(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get a mask at the specified cell.
member.param: The cell offset you want to get.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.GetCandidates(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the candidate mask part of the specified cell.
member.param: The cell offset you want to get.

returns.para:
The candidate mask. The return value is a 9-bit value, where each bit will be:
0 The cell doesn't contain the possibility of the digit.
1 The cell contains the possibility of the digit.
For example, if the result mask is 266 (i.e. 0b100_001_010 in binary), the value will indicate the cell contains the digit 2, 4 and 9.

member.summary: Gets the mask at the specified position. This method returns the reference of the mask.
member.returns: The reference to the mask that you want to get.

remarks.para: This method is a little bit different with . This method returns an modifiable reference, therefore the return value is instead of being used by that method, which means you cannot use it as an lvalue to update the mask. In addition, that method always returns the reference to the first element.

member.remarks: Please note that the method cannot be called with a correct behavior using to output. It seems that Visual Studio doesn't print correct values when indices of this grid aren't 0. member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.Parse(System.String)
M:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.Parse(System.String,System.Boolean)

summary.para: Parses a string value and converts to this type.

If you want to parse a PM grid, you should decide the mode to parse. If you use compatible mode to parse, all single values will be treated as given values; otherwise, recommended mode, which uses '<d>' or '*d*' to represent a value be a given or modifiable one. The decision will be indicated and passed by the second parameter .

member.param: Indicates whether the parsing operation should use compatible mode to check PM grid.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.ExtendedSusserEliminationsPattern
member.remarks:
Pattern explanation:
Zero-width positive lookbehind.
Match ':' right-to-left.
Loop greedily any number of times.
1st capture group.
Match a Unicode digit exactly 3 times.
Match a whitespace character atomically at least once.
Match a Unicode digit exactly 3 times.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Filtering.TechniqueFiltering.KeywordPattern
member.remarks:
Pattern explanation:
1st capture group.
Match with 2 alternative expressions, atomically.
Match a sequence of expressions.
Match a character in the set [Dd].
Match a character in the set [Ii\u0130].
Match a character in the set [Ff] exactly 2 times.
Match a character in the set [Ii\u0130].
Match a character in the set [Cc].
Match a character in the set [Uu].
Match a character in the set [Ll].
Match a character in the set [Tt].
Match a character in the set [Yy].
Match a sequence of expressions.
Match a character in the set [Nn].
Match a character in the set [Aa].
Match a character in the set [Mm].
Match a character in the set [Ee].

member.name: T:Sudoku.Generating.Puzzlers.PatternBasedPuzzleGenerator
member.summary: Indicates a puzzle generator that uses the pattern-based sudoku generation algorithm.
member.remarks:
The main idea can be shortened into the several following steps:
Randomize to generate a pattern which contains about 24 cells.
Randomize to get some numbers (Just about 3 digits is okay). These digits should guarantee the validity of the pattern.
Try to solve this as the multiple solution puzzle. Our aim in this step is to get a valid solution.
Remove digits not filled in the pattern.
Check validity of the removed puzzle. If the puzzle is unique, generated successfully, and return this puzzle; otherwise, adjust pattern slightly and try again. If failed after having tried 10000 times, we will re-generate a sudoku puzzle.

summary.para: Provides with the type that contains a module initializer method, called automatically by the CLR (Common Language Runtime) to initialize some values.

para.i: The type is called by the compiler and the CLR (Common Language Runtime), which means you cannot use any members in this type manually.

target.name: method
target.summary: Called by the runtime automatically while booting on this solution to initialize the values, data members or any other things that can or should be initialized here.
target.remarks: The concept module is different with assembly. The solution can contain multiple assemblies, while each assembly can contain multiple modules. However, due to the design of Visual Studio project file system, each assembly will only contain one module by default.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Recording.RecordableItem
member.summary: Defines a recordable item. This type is used for recording a user's behavior on finishing a sudoku puzzle.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Recording.RecordableItem._mask
member.summary: Indicates the inner mask.
member.remarks:
This field only uses 11 bits. The lower 10 bits to describe the candidate the user operates, and the 11th bit from lower means which kind of behavior that a user want to operate that candidate (set or delete). Other bits is reserved for later use. The sketch is like:
16 1110 0 |xxxx|| | |-------|-------| 16 8 0

member.name: P:Sudoku.Resources.Resources.TechniqueFormat_AlmostLockedSetsWWingStep
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to {Name}: Two ALSes {Als1Str}, {Als2Str} connected by {ConjStr}, W = {WStr}, X = {XStr} => {ElimStr}.

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to {Name}: {Als1Str} -> {BridgeStr} -> {Als2Str}, X = {XStr}, Y = {YStr}, Z = {ZStr} => {ElimStr}.

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to {Name}: ALS #1: {Als1Str}, ALS #2: {Als2Str}, X = {XStr}{ZResultStr} => {ElimStr}.

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to {Name}: Chain {ChainStr} => {ElimStr}.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Resources.Resources.TechniqueFormat_AvoidableRectangleWithHiddenSingleStep
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to {Name}: Digits {D1Str} and {D2Str} in {CellsStr} with hidden single: if cell {BaseCellStr} is filled with the digit {Digit1Str}, house {HouseStr} will only contain a cell {TargetCellStr} can be filled with that digit, but will raise the deadly pattern => {ElimStr}.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Resources.Resources.TechniqueFormat_BinaryChainingStep
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to {Name}: It can be proved to be a contradiction if {AnchorIsTrueOrFalseStr} is {AnchorIsNotOnStr} => {ElimStr}.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Resources.Resources.TechniqueFormat_BivalueOddagonType1Step
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to {Name}: If the cell {CellStr} only contains the digits {Digit1Str} and {Digit2Str} (or one of those two), the loop {LoopStr} will form an error structure => {ElimStr}.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.CommonReadOnlies.HouseCells

summary.para:
The map of all cell offsets in its specified house. The indices is between 0 and 26, where:
0..9 Block 1 to 9.
9..18 Row 1 to 9.
18..27 Column 1 to 9.

member.example: 'HouseCells[0]': all cell offsets in the house 0 (block 1).

.-------.-------.-------. | C C C | A A A | A A A | | B B B | . . . | . . . | | B B B | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
In addition, in this data structure, a CoverSet is a block and a BaseSet is a line.

remarks.para:
All disallowed properties are:
The disallowed method is:

Those properties or methods can optimize the performance to analyze a sudoku grid, but sometimes they may cause a potential bug that is hard to find and fix. The attribute is created and used for solving the problem.

member.summary: Indicates the difficulty level of the step. This enumeration type is used for the displaying of the step information list.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherDisplayingLevel.None
member.summary: Indicates the level is none.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherDisplayingLevel.A
member.summary: Indicates the level is the elementary searchers, which means the techniques found in the current step searcher is the elementary ones.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherDisplayingLevel.B
member.summary: Indicates the level is the moderate searchers, which means the techniques found in the current step searcher is more difficult than the elementary ones, but they aren't very difficult to comprehend the backing logic.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherDisplayingLevel.C
member.summary: Indicates the level is the hard searchers, which means the techniques found in the current step searcher is more difficult than the moderate ones.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherDisplayingLevel.D
member.summary: Indicates the level is the fiendish searchers, which means the techniques found in the current step searcher is more difficult than the hard ones.

summary.para: Indicates the level is the hidden searchers, which means the techniques found in the current step searcher should be hidden no matter how easy the technique is.
The well-known technique searcher of this level is Brute Force.

member.summary: Indicates nothing goes wrong.

summary.para: Indicates the failed reason is that the puzzle doesn't contain a valid unique solution.
Different with and , this field will include more generic cases. If the puzzle doesn't pass the pre-process operation before solving, we should use this field.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.PuzzleHasNoSolution
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the puzzle doesn't contain a valid solution.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.PuzzleHasMultipleSolutions
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the puzzle contains multiple valid solutions.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.UserCancelled
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the user has canceled the task.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.NotImplemented
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the solver or some searching module isn't implemented.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.ExceptionThrown
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the solver has encountered an error and couldn't solve that will cause an exception thrown.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.WrongStep
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the solver has found a wrong step that cause the grid become invalid.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.PuzzleIsTooHard
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the puzzle is too hard to solve. The solver gave up.

remarks.i: This option becomes deprecated at present because we has already implemented a step searcher that always produces a valid step, guaranteeing that the solver will never give up at all time.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherInitializationOptions
member.summary: Indicates the options for a step searcher used while searching.
member.param: Indicates the priority of this technique.
Indicates which areas the step searcher is enabled and works well. The default value is both and .

param.name: DisplayingLevel
param.para: Indicates the displaying level of this technique.
The display level means the which level the technique is at. All higher leveled techniques won't display on the screen when the searchers at the current level have found technique instances.

In order to enhance the performance, this attribute is used on a step gatherer. For example, if Alternating Inference Chain (AIC) is at the level but Forcing Chains (FC) is at the level , when we find any AIC technique instances, FC won't be checked at the same time.
This attribute is also used for grouping those the searchers, especially in Sudoku Explainer mode.

param.name: DisabledReason
param.para: Indicates whether the current searcher has bug to fix, or something else to describe why the searcher is (or should be) disabled.
The property must contain a value that differs with when the property isn't .

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Algorithms.Backtracking.BacktrackingSolver
member.summary: Defines a solver that can solve a sudoku puzzle, using backtracking algorithm.

remarks.para:
Please note that the current type has no optimization on solving. Therefore sometimes the puzzle will be extremely slowly to be solved although it is not very hard by manually solved. One of the examples satisfying the above condition is:
..............3.85..1.2.......5.7.....4...1...9.......5......73..2.1........4...9
The current solver may spend about 4.5 min on solving this puzzle.

For more information, please visit
this link .

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Algorithms.Backtracking.BacktrackingSolver.Solve(Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@)
member.summary: To solve the specified grid.

param.name: result
param.para: The result of the grid.
Different with other methods whose containing type is , this argument can be used no matter what the result value will be.

member.returns:
A ? value indicating whether the grid can be solved, i.e. has a unique solution. Please note that the method will return three possible values:
The puzzle has a unique solution.
The puzzle has multiple solutions.
The puzzle has no solution.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Conclusion
member.summary: Encapsulates a conclusion representation while solving in logic.
member.remarks: Two s can be compared with each other. If one of those two is an elimination (i.e. holds the value as the type), the instance will be greater; if those two hold same conclusion type, but one of those two holds the global index of the candidate position is greater, it is greater.

Process the calculation.
member.param: Indicates whether the searcher only searching for one step is okay.

remarks.para:
The diagrams:
ALP: abx aby | ab abz |
ALT: abcw abcx | abc abc abcy abcz |
Algorithm:

If the cell ab (in ALP) or abc (in ALT) is filled with the digit p, then the cells abx and aby (in ALP) and abcw and abcx (in ALT) can't fill the digit p. Therefore the digit p can only be filled into the left-side block.
If the block only contains those cells that can contain the digit p, the ALP or ALT will be formed, and the elimination is z (in ALP) and y and z (in ALT).
This algorithm uses a concept called Restricted Common Candidate (abbr. RCC) to limit the implementation. If you don't know that is an RCC, this link will tell you what is it.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Implementations.Searchers.AlternatingInferenceChainStepSearcher.MaxCapacity
member.remarks: The default value is 3000.

remarks.para:
This method use a very simple method to search for AICs. We should treat all AICs as "specialized" discontinuous nice loops. In this way we can get two kinds of chains:
Type 1:
A / \ B===C
(Strong link B == C, eliminate A)
Type 2:
A // \\ B---C
(Strong link A == B -- C == A, set A)
We should search for those two kinds of chains, and then encapsulates to a human-friendly view.

para.b: TODO: We should record the relations for the advanced nodes, in order to create a good look.

remarks.para:
When we implement on this, we should consider 5 cases in total:
One digit lies in 2 blocks in a row.
One digit lies in 2 blocks in a column.
One digit lies in 2 rows in a block.
One digit lies in 2 columns in a block.
One digit lies in 1 row and 1 column in a block. We should treat it as a special case because the intersection cell may be used in both locked candidates nodes. We should consider on both cases.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Implementations.Searchers.JuniorExocetStepSearcher.CheckCrossLineCells(Sudoku.Techniques.Patterns.ExocetPattern@,System.Int16)
member.summary: Checks for the validity of the cross-line cells, guaranteeing the target cells is valid in the full exocet map.

remarks.para: The main idea of this searching operation:

.-------.-------.-------. | C C C | A A A | A A A | | B B B | . . . | . . . | | B B B | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
For example, if the cells C form a locked candidates, there'll be two cases:
Pointing (Type 1): Cells A contains the digit, but cells B doesn't.
Claiming (Type 2): Cells B contains the digit, but cells A doesn't.

Therefore, the algorithm is: Use bitwise-or operator | to gather all candidate masks from cells A, cells B and cells C, and suppose the notation a is the mask result for cells A, b is the mask result for cells B, and c is the mask result for cells C. If the equation (c & (a ^ b)) != 0 is correct, the locked candidates exists, and the result of the expression c & (a ^ b) is a mask that holds the digits of the locked candidates.

Why this expression? a ^ b means the digit can only appear in either cells A or cells B. If both or neither, the digit won't contain the locked candidates structure. Because of the optimization of the performance, we use the predefined table to iterate on all possible location where may form a locked candidate.

If a group of all instances of N different digits in a chute is spread over max N+1 mini- rows/columns, then the group will contain at least one unavoidable set.

The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
cornerCell (ab ) abx aby abz xy *
Note: z is x or y.

member.summary: Check UR + 3X/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
cornerCell (ab ) abx | | b a | aby-----abz

member.summary: Check UR + 3N/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
cornerCell (ab )-----abx a | | b | aby abz

member.summary: Check UR + 3U/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
cornerCell (ab )-----abx a
b aby -----abz

member.summary: Check UR + 3E/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
cornerCell (ab )-----abx a
a aby -----abz

member.summary: Check UR + 4X/3SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
corner1, corner2 (abx)-----(aby) a | | b a | abz ----- abw

member.summary: Check UR + 4C/3SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.

remarks.para: The structures:

Subtype 1:
corner1, corner2 (abx)-----(aby) a | | a b | abz ----- abw

Subtype 2:
corner1, corner2 (abx)-----(aby) | a | | b | a | | abz abw

member.summary: Check UR-XY-Wing, UR-XYZ-Wing, UR-WXYZ-Wing and AR-XY-Wing, AR-XYZ-Wing and AR-WXYZ-Wing.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
The size of the wing to search.

remarks.para: The structures:

Subtype 1:
corner1 (ab ) abxy yz xz (ab ) abxy * corner2
Note that the pair of cells abxy should be in the same house.

Subtype 2:
corner1 (ab ) abx xz aby (ab ) * yz corner2

member.summary: Check UR + SdC.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
| xyz ab+ ab+ | abxyz abxyz | xyz ----------+------------ (ab)(ab) | corner1, corner2

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Implementations.Searchers.UniqueRectangleStepSearcher.CheckUnknownCoveringUnique(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Implementations.Steps.UniqueRectangleStep},Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,System.Int32[],System.Int16,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Check UR + Unknown covering.

remarks.para: The structures:

Subtype 1:
urCellInSameBlock ab abc abc anotherCell
abcx-----abcy resultCell c targetCell
Where the digit a and b in the bottom-left cell abcx can be removed.

Subtype 2:
abcx | ab abc | | | c | | | abcy | abc

summary.para: Check UR/AR + Guardian (i.e. UR External Type 2) and UR External Type 1.
A UR external type 1 is a special case for type 2, which means only one guardian cell will be used.

member.summary: Check UR/AR + Guardian, with external subset (i.e. UR External Type 3).
Check UR/AR + Guardian, with external conjugate pair (i.e. UR External Type 4).
Check UR/AR + Guardian, with external turbot fish.
Check UR/AR + Guardian, with external XY-Wing.
Check UR/AR + Guardian, with external ALS-XZ rule.
Check AR + Hidden single.
member.param: The map of other cells during the current UR searching.

remarks.para: The structure:

corner1 a | aby - - abx | a - b | - - - corner2(cell 'a')
There's only one cell can be filled with the digit 'b' besides the cell 'aby'.

member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is W-Wing ((x = y) - y = y - (y = x)).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Implementations.Steps.AlternatingInferenceChainStep.IsMWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is M-Wing ((x = y) - y = (y - x) = x).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Implementations.Steps.AlternatingInferenceChainStep.IsSplitWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is Split-Wing (x = x - (x = y) - y = y).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Implementations.Steps.AlternatingInferenceChainStep.IsHybridWing
member.summary:
Indicates whether the chain is Hybrid-Wing. This wing has two types:
(x = y) - y = (y - z) = z
(x = y) - (y = z) - z = z

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Implementations.Steps.AlternatingInferenceChainStep.IsLocalWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is Local-Wing (x = (x - z) = (z - y) = y).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Implementations.Steps.FishStep.Size
member.remarks:
The name of the corresponding names are:
2X-Wing
3Swordfish
4Jellyfish
5Squirmbag (or Starfish)
6Whale
7Leviathan
Other fishes of sizes not appearing in above don't have well-known names.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Implementations.Steps.UniqueRectangleStep
member.summary: Provides with a step that is a Unique Rectangle technique.

param.name: TechniqueCode2
param.para: Indicates the technique code.

Limited by the C# language, here we creates a new property to pass the value and assign it to the property . If write code to place the property into the primary constructor as a parameter, the default member named TechniqueCode may be duplicate with this parameter's, which isn't allowed in types in the language design.

member.param: Indicates the first digit used in this unique rectangle pattern.
Indicates the second digit used in this unique rectangle pattern.

param.name: IsAvoidable
param.para: Indicates whether the current unique rectangle is avoidable rectangle.
For the designation and the implementation, Avoidable Rectangle and Unique Rectangle are used as the same type.

param.name: AbsoluteOffset
param.para: Indicates the absolute offset.

The value will be an value to compare all possible cases of unique rectangle structures to be iterated. The greater the value is, the later the unique rectangle structure will be processed. The value must be between 0 and 485. Other values are invalid and useless. The number of all possible unique rectangle structures is 486.

member.summary: Provides the solver result after solving a puzzle.

summary.para: Indicates the maximum difficulty of the puzzle.

When the puzzle is solved by , the value will be the maximum value among all difficulty ratings in solving steps. If the puzzle has not been solved, or else the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be always 20.0M.
Indicates the total difficulty rating of the puzzle.

When the puzzle is solved by , the value will be the sum of all difficulty ratings of steps. If the puzzle has not been solved, the value will be the sum of all difficulty ratings of steps recorded in . However, if the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be 0.
Indicates the pearl difficulty rating of the puzzle, calculated during only by .
When the puzzle is solved, the value will be the difficulty rating of the first solving step. If the puzzle has not solved or the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be always 0.
Indicates the pearl difficulty rating of the puzzle, calculated during only by .

When the puzzle is solved, the value will be the difficulty rating of the first step before the first one whose conclusion is . If the puzzle has not solved or solved by other solvers, this value will be 20.0M.

member.summary: Indicates the number of all solving steps recorded.

member.summary: Indicates why the solving operation is failed. This property is useless when keeps the value.

member.summary: Indicates the difficulty level of the puzzle. If the puzzle has not solved or solved by other solvers, this value will be .

member.summary: Indicates a list, whose element is the intermediate grid for each step.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.LogicalSolverResult.Steps
member.summary: Indicates all solving steps that the solver has recorded.

summary.para: Indicates a list of pairs of information about each step.
If the puzzle cannot be solved due to some reason (invalid puzzle, unhandled exception, etc.), the return value of the property will be always the expression of type , of of types and .

Indicates the wrong step found. In general cases, if the property keeps value, it'll mean the puzzle is invalid to solve, or the solver has found one error step to apply, that causes the original puzzle become invalid. In this case we can check this property to get the wrong information to debug the error, or tell the author himself directly, with the inner value of this property held.
However, if the puzzle is successful to be solved, the property won't contain any value, so it'll keep the reference. Therefore, please check the nullability of this property before using.

In general, this table will tell us the nullability of this property:
Nullability Description
Not The puzzle is failed to solve, and the solver has found an invalid step to apply.
Other cases.

member.summary:
Provides with an Alternating Inference Chain step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Non-grouped chains:
Irregular Wings:
W-Wing (Although it can be searched via )
M-Wing
Split Wing
Local Wing
Hybrid Wing
Purple Cow
Discontinuous Nice Loop
Alternating Inference Chain
Continuous Nice Loop
Grouped chains:
Grouped Irregular Wings
Grouped Discontinuous Nice Loop
Grouped Alternating Inference Chain
Grouped Continuous Nice Loop

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Prototypes.IAlternatingInferenceChainStepSearcher.MaxCapacity
member.summary: Indicates the maximum capacity used for the allocation on shared memory.

summary.para: Indicates the extended nodes to be searched for. Please note that the type of the property is an enumeration type with bit-fields attribute, which means you can add multiple choices into the value.

You can set the value as a bit-field mask to define your own types to be searched for, where:
Field name Description (What kind of nodes can be searched)
The strong and weak inferences between 2 sole candidate nodes of a same digit (i.e. X-Chain).
The strong and weak inferences between 2 sole candidate nodes of a same cell (i.e. Y-Chain).
The strong and weak inferences between 2 nodes, where at least one node is a locked candidates node.
The strong inferences between 2 nodes, where at least one node is an almost locked set node.
The weak inferences between 2 nodes, where at least one node is an almost hidden set node.
The strong and weak inferences between 2 nodes, where at least one node is an almost unique rectangle node.
The strong and weak inferences between 2 nodes, where at least one node is an XYZ-Wing node.
The strong and weak inferences between 2 nodes, where at least one node is a kraken fish node.
Other typed inferences are being considered, such as an XYZ-Wing node, etc.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Prototypes.IAlternatingInferenceChainStepSearcher.IsNodesRedundant(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Checks whether the node list is redundant, which means the list contains duplicate link node IDs in the non- endpoint nodes.

summary.para:
Provides with a Bi-value Oddagon step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Bi-value Oddagon Type 2
Bi-value Oddagon Type 3
In practicing, type 1 and 4 do not exist. A bi-value oddagon type 1 is a remote pair and a type 4 cannot be formed as a stable technique structure.
A remote pair is a XY-Chain that only uses two digits. This technique will be resolved by .

Bi-value Universal Grave False Candidate Type

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Prototypes.IBivalueUniversalGraveStepSearcher.SearchExtendedTypes
member.summary: Indicates whether the searcher should call the extended BUG checker to search for all true candidates no matter how difficult searching.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Prototypes.IBivalueUniversalGraveStepSearcher.FindTrueCandidates(Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyList{System.Int32}@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Finds all possible true candidates in this current grid.
member.param: The grid to find all possible true candidates.
Indicates the maximum number of possible cells to check.
member.returns: A value indicating whether the grid contains any possible true candidates. If so, the argument won't be .
member.remarks: A true candidate is a candidate that makes the puzzle containing no valid solution if it is eliminated from the current puzzle. It is a strict concept, which means sometimes the puzzle doesn't contain any satisfied candidate to make the puzzle containing no solution if being eliminated.
member.exception: Throws when the puzzle contains multiple solutions or even no solution.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Prototypes.IBivalueUniversalGraveStepSearcher.FormsPattern(Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@)
member.summary: Checks whether the specified grid forms a BUG deadly pattern. This method does not use the cached buffers in type .

member.summary: Defines a step whose technique used is the elementary one.

Full House, Last Digit, Hidden Single, Naked Single
Pointing, Claiming
Naked Pair, Naked Triple, Naked Quadruple
Naked Pair (+), Naked Triple (+), Naked Quadruple (+)
Hidden Pair, Hidden Triple, Hidden Quadruple
Locked Pair, Locked Triple

A ? value indicating whether the grid can be solved, i.e. has a unique solution. Please note that the method will return three possible values:
The puzzle has a unique solution.
The puzzle has multiple solutions.
The puzzle has no solution.

member.summary: Provides a basic logical solving step.

summary.para: Indicates whether the difficulty rating of this technique should be shown in the output screen. Some techniques such as Gurth's symmetrical placement doesn't need to show the difficulty (because the difficulty of this technique is unstable).
If the value is , the analysis result won't show the difficulty of this instance.
The default value is .

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Prototypes.IStep.Name
member.summary: Indicates the technique name. The technique name are all stored in the resource dictionary, you can find them in the Resources folder (Type ).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Prototypes.IStep.Format
member.summary: Gets the format of the current instance.
member.returns: Returns a result. If the resource dictionary doesn't contain any valid formats here, the result value will be .

remarks.para: A format is the better way to format the result text of this technique information instance. It'll be represented by the normal characters and the placeholders, e.g. "{Name}: Cells {CellsStr} => {ElimsStr}" Here the string result shouldn't be with the leading '$' character, because this is a format string instead of an interpolated one.

Here the property Name, CellsStr and ElimsStr must have been implemented before the property invoked. You should create 3 properties whose names are Name, CellsStr and ElimsStr, and return the corresponding correct string result, making them non- (suggested keyword is ) and applying attribute to it.

Because this property will get the value from the resource dictionary, the property supports multiple language switching, which is better than the normal methods ToString and ToFullString. Therefore, this property is the substitution of those two methods.

param.para: If is set to , this argument will become useless because we only finding one step is okay, so we may not use the accumulator to store all possible steps, in order to optimize the performance. Therefore, this argument can be (i.e. the expression !) when the argument is .

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Prototypes.IStepWithRank
member.summary: Defines a step whose technique used is related to the rank theory, which contains the property Rank.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Prototypes.IStepWithRank.Rank
member.summary: Indicates the rank of the technique structure.
member.returns:
The return value can be separated with the following cases:
Range Description
> 1
The technique cannot be applied any eliminations except the intersection that all possible branches can see.
1
The technique can be applied eliminations that is like a normal AIC.
0
The technique can be applied eliminations that is like a nice loop. For example, a Sue de Coq.
<= 1
The negative rank value cannot be formed because the technique structure is at an invalid status.
member.remarks: Please note that sometimes a complex structure may not contain a valid and stable rank value. You can visit this link for more details about the mixed-rank structures.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Prototypes.IUniqueRectangleStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with a Unique Rectangle step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Basic types:
Unique Rectangle Type 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
Avoidable Rectangle Type 1, 2, 3, 5
Hidden Unique Rectangle
Hidden Avoidable Rectangle
Structured types:
Unique Rectangle + Conjugate Pair (also called "Unique Rectangle + Strong Link")
Avoidable Rectangle + Hidden Single
Unique Rectangle + Unknown Covering
Unique Rectangle + Sue de Coq
Unique Rectangle + Guardian (This program call it "Unique Rectangle External Types"):
Unique Rectangle External Type 1
Unique Rectangle External Type 2
Unique Rectangle External Type 3
Unique Rectangle External Type 4
Unique Rectangle External Type with XY-Wing
Unique Rectangle External Type with ALS-XZ
Avoidable Rectangle + Guardian (Sub-types are same like above)
Miscellaneous types:
Unique Rectangle 2D
Unique Rectangle 3X

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Prototypes.IUniqueRectangleStepSearcher.AllowIncompleteUniqueRectangles
member.summary: Indicates whether the UR can be incomplete. In other words, some of UR candidates can be removed before the pattern forms.
member.remarks:
For example, the complete pattern is:
ab | ab ab | ab
This is a complete pattern, and we may remove an ab in a certain corner. The incomplete pattern may not contain all four abs in the structure.

member.summary: Indicates whether the searcher can search for extended URs.

member.summary:
Indicates whether the corresponding technique of the current step is a chain. The chain techniques are:
Wings
Regular wings (XY-Wing, XYZ-Wing, WXYZ-Wing, etc.)
Irregular wings (W-Wing, M-Wing, Split-Wing, Local-Wing, Hybrid-Wing)
Short chains
Two strong links (Skyscraper, Two-string kite, Turbot fish)
ALS chaining-like techniques
ALS-XZ
ALS-XY-Wing
ALS-W-Wing
Empty rectangle
member.typeparam: The type of the step.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logics.Prototypes.StepExtensions.IsDeadlyPattern``1(``0)
member.summary:
Indicates whether the corresponding technique of the current step is a deadly pattern. The deadly pattern techniques are:
Bi-value patterns
Unique rectangle (i.e. Uniqueness test)
Unique loop
Bi-value universal grave
Multi-value patterns
Extended rectangle
Unique square
Unique polygon (Borescoper's deadly pattern as its alias)
Qiu's deadly pattern
member.typeparam: The type of the step.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Techniques.Patterns.AlternatingInferenceChain
member.summary:
Defines an alternating inference chain. The data structure can describe the following techniques:
Normal chains:
Irregular Wings
W-Wing
M-Wing
Split Wing
Local Wing
Hybrid Wing
Purple Cow
Discontinuous Nice Loop
Alternating Inference Chain
Continuous Nice Loop
Grouped chains (which means the nodes are not limited in sole candidates):
Grouped Wings
Grouped Discontinuous Nice Loop
Grouped Alternating Inference Chain
Grouped Continuous Nice Loop

member.name: M:Sudoku.Techniques.Patterns.AlternatingInferenceChain.#ctor(Sudoku.Techniques.Patterns.Node[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes an instance via the specified nodes and the value indicating whether the chain starts and ends with strong inferences.
member.param: Indicates whether the chain starts and ends with strong inferences.
member.exception: Throws when the length of the argument is less than or equals 3, or the first and the last node aren't the same when the argument is .

member.name: P:Sudoku.Techniques.Patterns.AlternatingInferenceChain.IsStrong
member.summary: Indicates whether the alternating inference chain starts with a strong inference, and ends with another strong inference.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Techniques.Patterns.AlternatingInferenceChain.HasNodeCollision
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain has a collision, encountered between start and end node. This property should be satisfied at least the chain is a grouped chain, and at least one of the first and the last node is a grouped node.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Techniques.Patterns.AlternatingInferenceChain.IsContinuousNiceLoop
member.summary: Indicates whether the current chain forms a continuous nice loop.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Techniques.Patterns.AlternatingInferenceChain.IsGrouped
member.summary: Indicates whether the current chain is a grouped chain.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Techniques.Patterns.AlternatingInferenceChain.IsIrregularWing
member.summary: Determines whether the current chain is an irregular wing (Chinese: Duan3 Lian4).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Techniques.Patterns.AlternatingInferenceChain.IsAlmostLockedSetsOnly
member.summary: Determines whether the chain only uses ALS grouped node as the strong inferences.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Techniques.Patterns.AlternatingInferenceChain.IsAlmostHiddenSetsOnly
member.summary: Determines whether the chain only uses AHS grouped node as the weak inferences.

member.summary: Indicates the full chain nodes, containing elimination nodes.

summary.para: Indicates the nodes that represents the main chain node data for the current chain.

The property value will be different if the property is different.
The value of the property Description
All nodes will be returned (i.e. _nodes[..]).
Returns the sliced array from the nodes being stored in the current instance, without the first and the last node (i.e. _nodes[1..^1]).

remarks.para: TODO: Append extra eliminations that requires the extended elimination rules.

e.g.
a. 25 | d. 28 b. 25 | e. 38 c. 3+ | f. 5+
Chain: a(5) == d(8) -- e(8 == 3) => b != 5, where the cell c and f are filled with modifiable values.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Techniques.Patterns.ExocetPattern

summary.para:
Indicates an exocet pattern. The pattern will be like:
.-------.-------.-------. | B B E | E . . | E . . | | . . E | Q . . | R . . | | . . E | Q . . | R . . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . S | S . . | S . . | | . . S | S . . | S . . | | . . S | S . . | S . . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . S | S . . | S . . | | . . S | S . . | S . . | | . . S | S . . | S . . | '-------'-------'-------'
Where:
BBase Cells.
Q1st Object Pair (Target cells pair 1).
R2nd Object Pair (Target cells pair 2).
SCross-line Cells.
EEscape Cells.

In the data structure, all letters will be used as the same one in this exemplar. In addition, if senior exocet, one of two target cells will lie in cross-line cells, and the lines of two target cells lying on can't contain any base digits.

member.param: Indicates the first target cell in the Q part.
Indicates the second target cell in the Q part.
Indicates the first target cell in the R part.
Indicates the second target cell in the R part.
Indicates the first mirror cell in the Q part.
Indicates the second mirror cell in the Q part.
Indicates the first mirror cell in the R part.
Indicates the second mirror cell in the R part.

member.summary:
Defines a pattern that is a Qiu's deadly pattern technique structure in theory. The sketch is like:
.-------.-------.-------. | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | | P P . | . . . | . . . | :-------+-------+-------: | S S B | B B B | B B B | | S S B | B B B | B B B | | . . . | . . . | . . . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
Where:
PPair Cells.
SSquare Cells.
BBase-line Cells.
member.param: The square cells that is S in that sketch.
The base-line cells that is B in that sketch.
The pair cells that is P in that sketch.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Techniques.Patterns.UniquePolygonPattern
member.summary:
Defines a pattern that is a unique polygon technique structure in theory. The sketch is like:
.-------.-------.-------. | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | P P . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . . | . . Q | S S . | | . . . | . . Q | S(S). | | . . . | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
Where:
PThe first group of cells.
QThe second group of cells.
S
The square cells of size 3 or 4. The cell with the bracket (r8c8 in the picture) is optional.
member.param: The mask that forms a structure.

remarks.para:
This is of type , where the distribution of each bit is as follows:
0 7 14 21 28 35 42 49 56
|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|
0 8 16 24 32 40 48 56 64
where the bit [0..56] is for 8 cells, the last 7 bits determine the pattern is a heptagon or a octagon. If the value is 127 (not available), the pattern will be a heptagon.
Due to the rendering engine, you have to check this file rather than the tip window.

Q | S S . | | . . . | . . Q | S(S). | | . . . | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
Where:

member.summary: Initialize an instance with the specified information.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Text.Formatting.GridFormatter.Multiline
member.summary: Indicates whether the output should be multi-line.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Text.Formatting.GridFormatter.WithModifiables
member.summary: Indicates the output should be with modifiable values.
member.returns: The output should be with modifiable values.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Text.Formatting.GridFormatter.WithCandidates

summary.para: Indicates the output should be with candidates. If the output is single line, the candidates will indicate the candidates-have-eliminated before the current grid status; if the output is multi-line, the candidates will indicate the real candidate at the current grid status.

If the output is single line, the output will append the candidates value at the tail of the string in ':candidate list'. In addition, candidates will be represented as 'digit', 'row offset' and 'column offset' in order.

member.returns: The output should be with candidates.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Text.Formatting.GridFormatter.TreatValueAsGiven
member.summary: Indicates the output will treat modifiable values as given ones. If the output is single line, the output will remove all plus marks '+'. If the output is multi-line, the output will use '<digit>' instead of '*digit*'.
member.returns: The output will treat modifiable values as given ones.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Text.Formatting.GridFormatter.SubtleGridLines
member.summary: Indicates whether need to handle all grid outlines while outputting.
member.returns: The result indicating whether need to handle all grid outlines while outputting.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Text.Formatting.GridFormatter.HodokuCompatible
member.summary: Indicates whether the output will be compatible with Hodoku library format.
member.returns: The result indicating whether the output will be compatible with Hodoku library format.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Text.Formatting.GridFormatter.Sukaku
member.summary: Indicates the output will be sukaku format (all single-valued digit will be all treated as candidates).
member.returns: The output will be sukaku format (all single-valued digit will be all treated as candidates).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Text.Formatting.GridFormatter.Excel
member.summary: Indicates the output will be Excel format.
member.returns: The output will be Excel format.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Text.Formatting.GridFormattingOptions.OpenSudoku
member.summary: Indicates the open sudoku format.
member.remarks: This format will use a triplet to describe a cell. If the cell has already been filled with a value, it will be output at the first digit of that triplet. For example, the triplet 900 means the cell is filled with the digit 9. In addition, if the cell is empty, the triplet is always 001.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Text.Notations.K9Notation
member.summary: Encapsulates a set of methods that handles a variety of instances, using K9 notation to output the representation, or parse a value to convert it to the suitable-typed instance.

remarks.para: The K9 notation is a notation to describe a set of cells that uses letters A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H and K to describe the row, and uses digits 1 to 9 to describe the column. For example, C8 means the cell at row 3 and column 8. The letter I and J aren't used in this notation because they are confusing with digit 1. However, they can also be used in Chinese notations, for example, K8 in traditional notation is same as I8 in Chinese K9 notation rule.
For more information about this concept, please visit this link.
Please note that the type is an type, which means you cannot instantiate any objects. In addition, the type contains a instance constructor, which disallows you deriving any types.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Text.Notations.K9Notation.Letters
member.summary: Indicates all possible letters that used in the row notation.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Text.Notations.K9Notation.CellOrCellListRegex
member.remarks:
Pattern explanation:
Match a character in the set [A-IKa-ik] atomically at least 1 and at most 9 times.
Match a character in the set [1-9] atomically at least 1 and at most 9 times.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Text.Notations.K9NotationOptions
member.summary: Provides with a type that is used for displaying a cell list, using K9 notation.
member.param: Indicates whether the method should use upper-casing to handle the result notation of cells. For example, if , the concept "row 3 column 3" will be displayed as C3; otherwise, c3.
Indicates whether the method should avoid confusion for the letter I and digit 1. For example, if , row 9 column 9 will be notated as K9; otherwise, I9.
Indicates the separator string value that inserts two coordinate elements, to combine them. For example, cells C1 and D2 can be combined to C1|D2 if the separator is "|".

member.name: T:Sudoku.Text.Notations.RxCyNotation
member.summary: Encapsulates a set of methods that handles a variety of instances, using RxCy notation to output the representation, or parse a value to convert it to the suitable-typed instance.

remarks.para: The RxCy notation is a notation to describe a set of cells that uses letter R (or its lower case r) to describe a row label, and uses the other letter C (or its lower case c) to describe a column label. For example, R4C2 means the cell at row 4 and column 2.
For more information about this concept, please visit this link.
Please note that the type is an type, which means you cannot instantiate any objects. In addition, the type contains a instance constructor, which disallows you deriving any types.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Text.Parsing.GridParsingOption
member.summary: Represents a grid parsing type.

summary.para: Indicates the susser format, which means all grid values will be displayed in one line with empty cell character '0' or '.'.
For example:

Indicates the shorten susser format, which means all grid values will be displayed in one line with empty cell character '0' or '.'. Different with the option , this option will continue shortening the code. The option will omit the continuous empty cells to a * in a single line. For example, the code
080630040200085009090000081000300800000020000006001000970000030400850007010094050
will be displayed as
08063*40,2*85009,09*81,*300800,*2*,006001*,97*30,40085*7,01*94050
via this option. We use the colon , to separate each line of 9 numbers, and then omit the most continuous empty cells to a *.
Indicates the pencil marked grid (PM grid), which means all grid candidates will be displayed using a table.
Indicates the table format, which means all grid values will be displayed using a table with empty cell character '0' or '.'.
Sudoku explainer format (9 characters in a row, and 9 rows).
Sukaku sudoku format (only contains the digits and the whitespace).
Sukaku single line format, which uses '0' to be a placeholder.
Excel sudoku format (only contains the digits and the tab character).
Open sudoku format.
